DISCUSSION Cap-dependent viral mRNAs are structurally similar to host mRNAs. vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) inhibits translation of host mRNAs in infected cells. the PRRSV genome also has a putative type I cap structure at its 5′ end. the translation of viral mRNAs is cap dependent (51, 52) there are several possible explanations for the exemption of viral translation from host translation shutoff. eIF2 is a key factor in the innate immune response to viral infection. phosphorylation of PKR and probably eIF2 is not the primary drivers to block the translation of herpes simplex virus true late mRNAs in the absence of virion host shutoff. 4E-BP1 is dephosphorylated during encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) infection. event is almost simultaneous with the shutoff of protein synthesis caused by EMCV (64). phosphorylation of mTOR, 4E-BP, and S6K is reduced 48 h after PRRSV infection (65) the TM domain of PRRSV nsp2 contains a transmembrane structure. it is possible that PRRSV nsp2 induces ER stress via its TM domain. this inactivates the mTOR signaling pathway during the formation of the arterivirus replication complex. the drug 4E2RCat reduces human coronavirus 229E replication and reduces both the intra- and extracellular infectious viral titers. two specific aptamers that recognize PABP1 reduce the expression of the viral genome and the production of infective influenza virus particles (77). at present, vaccination is the principal measure used to control and treat PRRSV infection.
